title: Effect of Mn, Ti and Sc Addition on Hardness in an Artificially Aged 2024 Al Alloy
content: Aluminum alloys are currently receiving significant attention due to their advantageous combination of low cost and density-to-strength ratio, leading to many applications [1, 2]. Numerous alloys have been developed, each with specific thermal treatment protocols [3, 4]. Among these alloys, AA2024 stands out for its extensive use across various industries, such as automotive and aerospace, attributed to its exceptional resistance to stress-corrosion cracking [5, 6]. Precipitation-hardened alloys, including those in the 2xxx, 6xxx, and 7xxx series, require precise control over the precipitation process to ensure the creation of high-performance alloys [7]. The strengthening primary precipitate in the 2xxx series is θ´ (Al2Cu) phase. At elevated temperatures, this precipitate undergoes coarsening, which is swiftly succeeded by a phase transformation to the stable θ phase. This transformation leads to a reduction in strength due to the coarsening of the newly formed phase. This process occurs rapidly at temperatures exceeding 250°C [8].
